awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Multi-level Research into I-Corps' Impact on Entrepreneurial Development:  An Exploratory Study
awd_abstract_narration:
This EAGER project engages in research that has the potential to be transformative in the field of innovation. The project involves a study that evaluates the individual and combined effects of Innovation Corps (I-Corps) activities to explore the multi-level impact on entrepreneurial development of participants. 

Research on entrepreneurship and in the related fields of economics, psychology, and sociology has found that new business creation is affected by a wide range of factors at multiple levels of analysis (individual, team, organization, community, industry, and economy). I-Corps, with its entrepreneurship training offered at different levels, formats and from different locations across the country, provides a unique setting to collect data conducive to interdisciplinary, multi-level investigation of new business creation with a focus on technology startup firms originating from innovations developed on university campuses. The research and the data that it collects on program activities and impact will help advance future research and the development of more comprehensive theories about technology commercialization and new business creation. The outcomes will inform the next generation of entrepreneurship training and startup strategies, and, it will also help advance fundamental knowledge about the key determinants of entrepreneurial success and the development of appropriate metrics for its evaluation. It will enable future innovation research and the development of more comprehensive theories about technology commercialization and new business creation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the training impact of NSF's Innovation Corps Program (or I-Corps) on participants' entrepreneurial development relative to those of non-I-Corps training provided on university campuses.  It also examined whether I-Corps' training impact is uniform or different across participant groups with varying personal and academic or professional backgrounds.

 

Adapted from lean startup methodologies, I-Corps focuses its training on customer discovery in developing a marketable product idea by engaging participants in field interviews with potential customers.  Training is offered in a workshop format offered at the local, regional, and national level.  National I-Corps workshops are seven weeks long.  Those at the local and regional level are usually shorter in duration and require fewer customer interviews.

 

Longitudinal data were collected from a total of 1,324 subjects (students, faculty, postdocs, staff, and other affiliates) across eight U.S. universities in different regional locations over a 12-month period (with different start dates).   Each subject was invited to complete four online surveys including the baseline at the outset and three follow-on trimonthly ones.  Around 45% of the subjects had taken an I-Corps workshop at either the local/regional or national level, with half of them having taken both.  The other 55% had received only non-I-Corps entrepreneurial training.

 

Following are some of the preliminary findings based on regression analysis of data from the initial baseline survey.  Because these data are cross-sectional in nature, the word "impact" is used below to mean an observed statistical effect or association between a dependent and a focal independent variable within the context of a multiple regression equation.  While one can infer causality from these observed statistical effects based on logical grounds, these effects will need to be further investigated using longitudinal data or other methods before drawing conclusions.

 

I-Corps vs. Non-I-Corps Impact

I-Corps training in general had an independent positive impact on participants' entrepreneurial development over and above those from non-I-Corps training programs.  The latter includes specialized seminars on startup business, one-on-one and small group mentoring, formal course work on entrepreneurship, and venture/business plan competition.  Entrepreneurial development was measured in terms of confidence in ability to launch and manage a business, motivation to start a business, and propensity to start a business within the next three years.  I-Corps' impact was strongest on propensity to start a business, followed by motivation, confidence to launch, and weakest on confidence to manage a business.

 

I-Corps' impact on confidence to launch and manage a business ranked 4th behind those of specialized seminars on startup business (1st), mentoring (2nd), and formal course work on entrepreneurship (3rd).  Its impact on motivation and propensity to start a business ranked 2nd behind specialized seminars on startup business (1st).  The combined impact of I-Corps and these three other training programs was on average 2.72 times larger than that of I-Corps alone across the four measures of entrepreneurial development.

 

Taken together, these preliminary findings confirm the value-add of I-Corps but also show that it is more impactful on increasing participants' motivation and propensity to start a business than enhancing their ability to launch and manage a business.  The findings are also consistent with the original intent of I-Corps to focus its training on customer discovery which is a necessary but not sufficient condition for startup success.  Given the persistent high failure rates of new businesses, particularly among the tech startups, more is needed to help I-Corps participants further develop their ability to launch and manage a business.   

 

I-Corps' Differential Impacts

Significant differences were found in I-Corps' training impact across racial groups.  Specifically, regression results show that its positive impact on participants across the four measures of entrepreneurial development is strongest among Whites and Hispanics, followed by Asians, and weakest among Blacks.  For the latter, mentoring had the strongest positive impact on confidence to launch a business.  

 

While no significant differences in I-Corps' training impact on entrepreneurial development were found between males and females, results show that participants with a STEM disciplinary background benefited most from I-Corps training relative to those majoring in other academic fields including business, arts and humanities, and the social sciences. 

 

The above findings point to the need for research into the underlying causes of these differential impacts and finding ways to make I-Corps training equally beneficial to participants of different personal and academic or professional backgrounds.

 

Next Steps

Currently, we are in the process of merging data from the baseline and the three follow-on trimonthly surveys into a combined dataset for longitudinal analysis.  This will allow a more rigorous analysis of the data with greater causal inference of I-Corps' training impact than the findings reported above which are based on cross-sectional data from the baseline survey.  The combined dataset will also make it possible to examine relationships between I-Corps training and other antecedent and outcome variables that are only present in the three trimonthly surveys.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2023
Modified by: Joseph Cheng
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project investigated the training impact of NSF's Innovation Corps Program (or I-Corps) on participants' entrepreneurial development relative to those of non-I-Corps training provided on university campuses.  It also examined whether I-Corps' training impact is uniform or different across participant groups with varying personal and academic or professional backgrounds.

 

Adapted from lean startup methodologies, I-Corps focuses its training on customer discovery in developing a marketable product idea by engaging participants in field interviews with potential customers.  Training is offered in a workshop format offered at the local, regional, and national level.  National I-Corps workshops are seven weeks long.  Those at the local and regional level are usually shorter in duration and require fewer customer interviews.

 

Longitudinal data were collected from a total of 1,324 subjects (students, faculty, postdocs, staff, and other affiliates) across eight U.S. universities in different regional locations over a 12-month period (with different start dates).   Each subject was invited to complete four online surveys including the baseline at the outset and three follow-on trimonthly ones.  Around 45% of the subjects had taken an I-Corps workshop at either the local/regional or national level, with half of them having taken both.  The other 55% had received only non-I-Corps entrepreneurial training.

Because these data are cross-sectional in nature, the word "impact" is used below to mean an observed statistical effect or association between a dependent and a focal independent variable within the context of a multiple regression equation. I-Corps training in general had an independent positive impact on participants' entrepreneurial development over and above those from non-I-Corps training programs.  The latter includes specialized seminars on startup business, one-on-one and small group mentoring, formal course work on entrepreneurship, and venture/business plan competition.  Entrepreneurial development was measured in terms of confidence in ability to launch and manage a business, motivation to start a business, and propensity to start a business within the next three years.  I-Corps' impact was strongest on propensity to start a business, followed by motivation, confidence to launch, and weakest on confidence to manage a business.

 

I-Corps' impact on confidence to launch and manage a business ranked 4th behind those of specialized seminars on startup business (1st), mentoring (2nd), and formal course work on entrepreneurship (3rd).  Its impact on motivation and propensity to start a business ranked 2nd behind specialized seminars on startup business (1st). Given the persistent high failure rates of new businesses, particularly among the tech startups, more is needed to help I-Corps participants further develop their ability to launch and manage a business.

Significant differences were found in I-Corps' training impact across racial groups.  Specifically, regression results show that its positive impact on participants across the four measures of entrepreneurial development is strongest among Whites and Hispanics, followed by Asians, and weakest among Blacks.  For the latter, mentoring had the strongest positive impact on confidence to launch a business.  

 

While no significant differences in I-Corps' training impact on entrepreneurial development were found between males and females, results show that participants with a STEM disciplinary background benefited most from I-Corps training relative to those majoring in other academic fields including business, arts and humanities, and the social sciences. 

 

The above findings point to the need for research into the underlying causes of these differential impacts and finding ways to make I-Corps training equally beneficial to participants of different personal and academic or professional backgrounds.

Currently, we are in the process of merging data from the baseline and the three follow-on trimonthly surveys into a combined dataset for longitudinal analysis.  This will allow a more rigorous analysis of the data with greater causal inference of I-Corps' training impact than the findings reported above which are based on cross-sectional data from the baseline survey.  The combined dataset will also make it possible to examine relationships between I-Corps training and other antecedent and outcome variables that are only present in the three trimonthly surveys.
